Navigation
Name Rascal/Libraries/lang/xml/DOM
Synopsis Functions for reading and writing XML files using DOM.
Usage import lang::xml::DOM;
Details Node attribute element parseXMLDOM parseXMLDOMTrim xmlCompact xmlPretty xmlRaw
Description The Document Object Model DOM is a cross-platform and language-independent way of representing and manipulating HTML, XHTML and XML documents. We use a version of DOM called JDOM.

The typical processing of an XML document will contain (depending on the application) a combination of the following steps:
  • Read the XML file as a string using readFile.
  • Parse and convert that string to a DOM instance using one of parseXMLDOM or parseXMLDOMTrim. The result is a value of type xml/DOM/Node.
  • Extract information from the DOM instance (typically using pattern matching or visits).
  • Transform the DOM instance to another, non-XML, representation.
  • Transform the DOM instance or create a new one.
  • Write a DOM instance to a file using xmlRaw, xmlCompact, or xmlPretty.
The following functions are provided:
  • Node: Datatypes for representing an instance of the DOM.
  • attribute: Auxiliary constructor for XML attribute without namespace.
  • element: Auxiliary constructor for XML element without namespace.
  • parseXMLDOM: Parse an XML document and return a DOM instance.
  • parseXMLDOMTrim: Parse an XML document and trim it (remove layout).
  • xmlCompact: Convert a DOM instance to a compact XML string (with minimal white space).
  • xmlPretty: Convert a DOM instance to a pretty printed XML string.
  • xmlRaw: Convert a DOM instance to a raw XML string.
Examples We will use the following example XML file that represents simple notes: 
<note>
<to>Jurgen</to>
<to>Tijs</to>
<from>Paul</from>
<date>2012-04-01</date>
<heading font="bold">Reminder</heading>
<body>Don't forget to run the Rascal tests!</body>
</note>
We can, for instance, read this XML file and extract all <to> ... </to> elements from it: 
rascal>import IO;
ok
rascal>import lang::xml::DOM;
ok
rascal>D = parseXMLDOM(readFile(|tutor:///Rascal/Libraries/lang/xml/note.xml|));
|stdin:///|(16,55,<1,16>,<1,71>): PathNotFound(|tutor:///Rascal/Libraries/lang/xml/note.xml|)
	somewhere in: public org.eclipse.imp.pdb.facts.IValue org.rascalmpl.library.Prelude.readFile(org.eclipse.imp.pdb.facts.ISourceLocation,org.rascalmpl.interpreter.IEvaluatorContext)
	somewhere in: ___SCREEN_INSTANCE___
With the DOM instance D available we can extract the strings from all to elements: 
rascal>for(/element(_,"to",/str N) := D) 
>>>>>>>    println(N);
|stdin:///|(31,1,<1,31>,<1,32>): Undeclared variable, function or constructor: D
This can be read as follows:
  • Create the DOM instance D for the note file.
  • Match the D for elements that have "to" as second field. Such an element looks like: element(none(),"to",[charData("Jurgen")]). We use a Descendant pattern / to achieve this: first to find the nested element with a "to" field, and then to find the embedded string in that element.
  • From the matching elements, extract the name string N that is embedded in the third field.
  • Print the name N.
